questions.question: Question 1: What is the recommended age for starting screening mammography?
questions.explanation:
The recommended age for women to start annual screening mammography is 40 years of age. • Until 44 years of age, it is her individual choice to decide on whether she wants screening 
mammography or not. • For ages between 45 and 49 years, it is mandatory to get annual breast screening done. • After the age of 50 years, it is advised that women get a second yearly screening done.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is false regarding screening mammography?

options.a: Sensitivity of the test will increase with her age.
options.b: It is best performed in the 2nd half of her menstrual cycle.
options.c: Mediolateral oblique view will show the greatest volume of her breast tissue.
options.d: Craniocaudal view will provide better visualization of the medial aspect of her breast.

questions.explanation:
Mammography is best performed in the 1st half of the menstrual cycle, as breast tissue is less 
dense in the follicular phase. Also, in the 2nd half of the menstrual cycle, since ovulation occurs 
and there is a chance for pregnancy, the radiation can potentially affect the embryo. The sensitivity of mammography increases with age, as the breast tissue becomes less dense. It involves 2 standard views: • Mediolateral oblique (MLO) view- covers a greater volume of breast tissue, including the upper 
outer quadrant and the axillary tail of Spence. • Craniocaudal (CC) view- provides better visualization of the medial aspect of the breast. Mammography uses low-voltage, high-amperage X-rays. The radiation dose from mammography 
is around 0.1 cGy per study.

questions.question:
Question 3: A 50-year-old woman underwent screening mammography. Which of the following findings 
in her mammogram is least suggestive of a malignancy?
questions.explanation:
Macrocalcification in a lesion is least suggestive of a malignancy. It is commonly seen in benign 
breast disorders. Microcalcification (<0.5 mm in diameter) is suggestive of malignancy. Table: Mammographic appearance of benign and malignant masses Below is an image showing a malignant breast mass with ill-defined, spiculated margins 
and microcalcifications. 226

questions.question:
Question 4: Which pattern of microcalcification seen in a patient’s mammography report would indicate 
the maximum risk of malignancy?
questions.explanation:
Cluster microcalcification in mammography indicates the maximum risk of malignancy. 227 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 5: Match the following types of calcifications with the diseases they are associated with.
questions.explanation:
Popcorn calcification is seen in fibroadenoma. Lead-pipe/egg-shell calcification is seen in traumatic fat necrosis. Broken-needle type of calcification is seen in duct ectasia. Tea-cup calcification is seen in fibrocystic disease. Popcorn calcification: Lead-pipe/egg-shell calcification: 228 
Sold by @itachibot Broken-needle type of calcification: Tea-cup calcification: 229 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 6: A 58-year-old woman presents with complaints of a painless lump in her left breast which she 
noticed during a routine self-examination. On palpation, a hard lump with irregular margins 
and enlarged left axillary lymph nodes were found. Which among the following is the best 
modality to detect malignancy in her case?
questions.explanation:
Tomosynthesis (3D mammography) performed along with conventional 2D mammography is the 
best investigation among the given options to detect breast carcinoma. Breast Tomosynthesis is typically performed in conjunction with conventional mammography. 
Hence, the radiation dose is doubled. However, the accuracy is improved and false positives are 
lesser. It can be used for dense breasts and those with high-risk factors. Screen-film mammography is the conventional 2D mammography. Digital mammography/full-field digital mammography uses digital technology instead of films. 
The diagnostic accuracy is similar to that of screen-film mammography. A minor advantage is the 
greater accuracy in predicting lesions in dense breasts. Note: Overall, the best modality for detecting breast carcinoma is MRI. The below image shows a comparison of 2D mammogram vs. 3D mammogram: 230 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 7: A mammogram done for a 45-year-old female patient with a breast lump was reported as 
BIRADS category 0. What is it suggestive of?
questions.explanation: Category/score 0 in BIRADS suggests an incomplete assessment. All breast imaging should be reported by BIRADS (breast imaging-reporting and data system).

questions.question:
Question 8: 220 
Sold by @itachibot A 48-year-old woman with a lump in her right breast was advised to undergo mammography 
which was reported as BIRADS 3. What will be the appropriate next step of management in 
this patient?
questions.explanation:
A BIRADS score of 3 means that it is probably a benign lesion. The next appropriate step is to 
follow up with this patient every 6 months for the next 2 years. During this period, the score can either downgrade to BIRADS 2 or upgrade to BIRADS 4 or 5.

questions.question:
Question 9: An anxious 45-year-old woman presented with complaints of a lump over her left breast for 2 
months. The patient underwent mammography, and the lump was categorized as BIRADS 4a. 
What is the likelihood of her lesion being malignant?
questions.explanation:
There is a 2-10% likelihood for a lesion with BIRADS 4a to be malignant. BIRADS Categories/Grades Grades 1 and 2: 0% chance of being malignant. Grade 3: >0% but 2% chance of being malignant Grade 4: • 4a: >2 to 10% chance of being malignant • 4b: >10 to 50% chance of being malignant • 4c: >50 to <95% chance of being malignant Grade 5:  95% chance of being malignant 231 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 10: A 36-year-old pregnant lady was referred to the surgery OPD at 12 weeks of gestation with a 
lump in her right breast for the past 1 month. On examination, a lump of 2 x 1 cm size was 
palpated in the upper outer quadrant of the breast. Which of the following investigations 
would you initially advise her for the assessment of the breast lump?
questions.explanation:
Ultrasonography (USG) is the preferred initial investigation in pregnant women who present with 
a breast lump. It can differentiate between solid and cystic lesions of the breast and is able to 
detect abnormal axillary lymph nodes. USG is preferred in women with dense breast tissue such 
as: • Pregnant women • Lactating women • Young women (less than 40 years old) Conventional Mammography/ Tomosynthesis with 2D mammography is less useful in pregnant 
women due to the increased density of breast tissue. MRI is not the initial investigation used for the assessment of breast lumps. It can be used in 
cases where metastasis or spread to other breasts is suspected.

questions.question:
Question 11: A USG can detect lymph node metastases in a patient with breast cancer and clinically 
negative lymph nodes by what percentage?
questions.explanation:
A USG can detect lymph node metastasis in a patient with clinically negative lymph nodes by 
50-60%. The clinical determination of axillary lymph node metastases has an accuracy of only 33%. Ultrasound (USG) is more sensitive than physical examination alone in determining axillary 
lymph node involvement during the preliminary staging of breast carcinoma. Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) or core biopsy of sonographically indeterminate or 
suspicious lymph nodes can provide a more definitive diagnosis than USG alone. Ultrasonography can also be utilized to image the regional lymph nodes in patients with breast 
cancer. The sensitivity for the status of axillary nodes ranges from 35% to 82% and specificity 
ranges from 73% to 97%. The features of a lymph node involved with cancer on USG include: • Cortical thickening • Change in shape of the node to a more circular appearance • Size larger than 10 mm • Absence of a fatty hilum • Hypoechoic internal echoes

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following features on USG will not be suggestive of breast malignancy?

options.d: Lump will be taller than wider

questions.explanation:
232 
Sold by @itachibot Malignant breast lump on USG, has an ill-defined echogenic halo, is hypoechoic, and the lump 
will be taller than wider. Benign breast lumps have a thin echogenic pseudo-capsule on USG.

questions.question:
Question 13: A young female patient presents to the clinic with a painless lump in her right breast. She 
underwent breast augmentation surgery 3 years back. Which of the following will be the best 
investigation to assess the breast tissue in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the best investigation to assess breast tissue in a patient 
with a breast implant. MRI of the breast is also used in: • Screening of high-risk individuals with a positive family history. • Assessing loco-regional spread (multifocality and multicentricity) of carcinoma. • To differentiate scar from recurrence in women who have had breast conservation surgery for 
breast cancer. Option A: Tomosynthesis is not preferred, as radio-opaque implants are usually compressed 
together with the breast tissue, obscuring the visibility and thereby reducing its sensitivity. Option B: Ultrasonography is used as an initial investigation in the evaluation of breast 
abnormalities in patients with breast implants. Option D: Computed tomography is not routinely used in the evaluation of breast lumps.

questions.question:
Question 14: A 40-year-old woman with an elder sister with BRCA1 gene mutation presented to the OPD 
with a normal mammography report. Which of the following is the next preferred 
investigation to further evaluate this patient?
questions.explanation:
In the given scenario, since the patient is at high risk for breast malignancy (first degree relative 
with BRCA1 gene mutation), MRI followed by trucut biopsy will be the appropriate next step for 
further evaluation. MRI is helpful in the screening of high-risk individuals and is the most sensitive imaging 
modality. However, it should be done after initial radiological evaluation, in case the results are 
inconclusive. American Cancer Society Risk Criteria for Breast Magnetic Resonance Imaging Screening: Women at high lifetime risk (20%-25% or greater) of breast cancer- • Known BRCA1 or BRCA2 gene mutation • First-degree relatives with BRCA1 or BRCA2 gene mutation, but have not had genetic testing 
themselves. • Radiation therapy to the chest between the ages of 10 and 30 years • Li-Fraumeni syndrome or Cowden syndrome or a first-degree relative with one of these 
syndromes. Women with a personal history of breast cancer, ductal carcinoma in situ, lobular carcinoma in 
situ, atypical ductal hyperplasia, or atypical lobular hyperplasia, are at a moderately increased 
lifetime risk for breast cancer. 233 
Sold by @itachibot Options A & D: Breast tomosynthesis or repeat mammography is not preferred as the next 
investigation in high-risk patients. Option C: Trucut biopsy will be done following MRI in high-risk patients.

questions.question:
Question 15: 222 
Sold by @itachibot A postmenopausal woman who was on HRT for the past 2 years, presented with a 4 x 3cm 
lump over the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. On examination, a peau d’orange 
appearance was seen and a hard and fixed lump was palpated over the breast. Which of the 
following is the investigation of choice to confirm the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The history and physical examination point towards a diagnosis of breast malignancy. The 
investigation of choice for confirmation of breast carcinoma is trucut biopsy/core-needle biopsy. 
An excisional biopsy can be done, in case it is inconclusive. Trucut needle biopsy permits the analysis of breast tissue architecture. A 14 G- 16 G needle is 
used. The advantages include a low complication rate, minimal scarring, and a lower cost as 
compared to excisional breast biopsy. Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is a cytological investigation and, hence, not the 
investigation of choice. A 22-30 G needle is used for FNAC. Trucut biopsy is preferred over FNAC as it: • Allows a definitive preoperative diagnosis • Differentiates between DCIS and invasive disease • Allows the tumor to be stained for receptor status, which is important for starting neoadjuvant 
therapy. Image-guided biopsy is used only in the case of non-palpable lesions.

questions.question:
Question 16: As a surgery resident, which of the following will you perform in a patient with suspected 
breast malignancy as part of the triple assessment?
questions.explanation:
Triple assessment in relation to breast carcinoma includes the following: • Clinical assessment includes both history and clinical examination • Radiological imaging, including ultrasonography (USG) and/or mammography • Histopathological examination (HPE), including fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) and/or 
Tru-Cut biopsy The positive predictive value of the triple assessment is 99.9%. Note: Bailey & Love 27th Ed mentions that clinical assessment, radiological imaging, and 
HPE constitute triple assessment. However, clinical assessment includes both history and clinical 
examination. Hence, history is a part of the triple assessment.

questions.question:
Question 17: An actress with bilateral silicone breast implants presents for regular follow-up. On 
radiological evaluation, she was found to have signs suggestive of intracapsular breast 
implant rupture. Which of the following named signs will you see on imaging?
questions.explanation:
Linguine sign (on MRI) and Stepladder sign (on USG) are specific for intracapsular breast implant 
rupture. 234 
Sold by @itachibot After implantation of a silicone or saline breast implant, a fibrous capsule (scar) forms around the 
implant shell. In an intracapsular rupture, the contents of the implant are contained by the 
fibrous scar, while the free-floating shell appears as a group of wavy lines (like the Italian linguine 
pasta as shown below). Hence, this has been termed the "linguine sign". Stepladder sign (seen on USG) is identified as multiple, discontinuous, parallel, linear echoes in 
the lumen as shown below. 235 
Sold by @itachibot Snowstorm sign (seen on USG) is seen in extracapsular rupture of breast implant. Comet tail sign is a finding that can be seen on chest CT. The comet-tail sign is produced by the 
distortion of vessels and bronchi that lead to an adjacent area of round atelectasis, which is the 
mass. The bronchovascular bundles appear to be pulled into the mass and resemble a comet tail. Note: Detection of intracapsular silicone ruptures is almost impossible on mammography.

questions.question:
Question 18: A woman came with complaints of breast pain following surgery. Her MRI is shown below. 
What is the likely diagnosis? 223 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The above image shows curvilinear hypointense lines (arrows) in the left breast implant indicative 
of the collapsed shell floating in the silicone gel. This is called the linguine sign that is seen 
in intra-capsular rupture of a breast implant. After implantation of a silicone or saline breast implant, a fibrous capsule (scar) forms around the 
implant shell. In an intracapsular rupture, the contents of the implant are contained by the 
fibrous scar, while the shell appears as a group of wavy lines. This has been termed the "linguine sign" and has been most commonly described with MR 
imaging. Multiple hyperintense foci on T2-weighted images are sometimes found within the implant 
lumen. These findings are referred to as the salad oil sign or droplet sign. Indications for breast MRI: • Screening for DCIS in high-risk patients • Evaluation of breast implants • Evaluation of breast scar tissue versus recurrent tumors. Ultrasound is the preferred modality of imaging in suspected cases of extracapsular rupture. The 
snowstorm sign on USG is seen in extracapsular rupture. 236 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 19: A 50-year-old female patient presents with a 4*3cm irregular mass in the upper outer 
quadrant of the right breast, which is not fixed to the skin or the chest wall. A lymph node of 
2cm is palpated in the right axilla. No mass is palpated in the opposite breast. Which of the 
following investigations would you perform on this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of breast malignancy with locoregional spread with 
unlikely distant metastasis. For further evaluation of this lesion, bilateral mammography, a 
biopsy of the breast mass and a USG-guided biopsy of the suspicious lymph node need to be 
performed in order to determine staging and decide on further management. Statement 2: PET Scan is usually performed in advanced cases of breast cancer. It is not routinely 
used in the assessment of locoregional disease. Statement 1: Diagnostic mammography is used to evaluate women with abnormal findings such as 
a breast mass or nipple discharge. Mammography is more accurate than clinical examination for 
the detection of early breast cancers. Mammographic features suggestive of breast cancer include 
a solid mass with or without stellate features, microcalcifications, irregular soft tissue shadow, 
spiculations and duct distortion. Statement 3: Pathological diagnosis of carcinoma is made by a core needle biopsy (tru-cut biopsy) 
or fine-needle aspiration before any type of treatment is started. Statement 4: The presence or absence of axillary lymph node involvement in breast cancer is one 
of the most important prognostic factors for determining staging and treatment. 
Ultrasound-guided lymph node biopsy should be done in patients with suspicious or clinically 
palpable lymph nodes. Ultrasound features suggestive of breast cancer include a hypoechoic, irregular mass with 
indistinct, angulated or spiculated margins, acoustic shadowing, ductal extension and a branched 
pattern of mass.

questions.question:
Question 20: A 22-year-old woman is found to have the BRCA1 mutation. She got herself tested after her 
mother’s death due to breast cancer with a BRCA1 mutation. At what age and with which 
modality would you start breast cancer screening in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Patients with BRCA mutations or positive known first-degree family history are considered 
high-risk patients. These patients need to undergo annual screening MRI + Mammogram from the 
age of 25yrs. Patients with a family history of breast cancer but no known gene mutation should also start 
screening before 40 years. Screening should begin 10 years before the earliest age of diagnosis of 
breast cancer in the first-degree relative. E.g- If the mother was detected with breast cancer at 40 
years of age, the daughter should start screening by the age of 30 years. High-risk patients for breast cancer: • Women with a known BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation • Two first-degree relatives with breast cancers with or without gene mutations • Women with a history of chest irradiation between the ages of 10 and 30 • 2 or more cases of breast cancer < 50 years old in the family • Mutation (or a first-degree relative with a mutation) in the TP53 or PTEN genes 237 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 21: A young woman with a distant breast cancer relative comes to you in the clinic. You are 
advising her to practice self-examination of her breasts. Which of the following statements is 
incorrect regarding this practice?
questions.explanation:
Self-examination of breasts can be done while standing or lying down. It should be ideally be done once a month, every month between the 3rd to 6th day of the 
menstrual cycle. If the periods are irregular or the patient is post-menopausal, then the patient 
can pick any day of the month. It can be done any time of the day while showering, dressing, standing, or lying down at night. Steps of the self-examination: • Visual inspection: See for any abnormalities, like shape, size, dimpling, puckering of the skin, 
nipple discharge, etc. • Manual inspection: It is done by using the middle three fingerpads. Feel for any lumps. 
Techniques used are (either one of them): • Horizontal stripes method • Vertical stripes method • Dial clock method Be sure to check under the areola and press the nipple gently to check for any discharge. 238 
Sold by @itachibot Carcinoma Breast - Staging, Prognosis & Molecular Types
